content.title: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
content.summary: DIC is a consumptive coagulopathy characterized by systemic activation of coagulation pathways leading to widespread microvascular thrombosis and simultaneous consumption of clotting factors and platelets, resulting in bleeding. It is always secondary to an underlying condition and treatment focuses on addressing the trigger.
key_points: Always secondary to underlying disease: sepsis, trauma, malignancy, obstetric complications
Pathophysiology: systemic thrombin generation → microvascular thrombosis + factor/platelet consumption → bleeding
Laboratory: prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer, thrombocytopenia, schistocytes
Treat underlying cause - this is paramount; supportive care with blood products
Acute overt DIC: bleeding predominates; Chronic DIC: thrombosis may predominate (Trousseau syndrome)
ISTH DIC scoring system helps diagnose overt DIC (score ≥5)
content.statement: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a syndrome of systemic coagulation activation always triggered by an underlying disorder, characterized by simultaneous microvascular thrombosis and consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding, requiring treatment of the underlying cause and supportive blood product therapy.

explanation.intuition: Think of DIC as the coagulation system in 'overdrive' - massive tissue factor release triggers widespread clotting that consumes all the clotting factors and platelets faster than the body can make them. You're clotting AND bleeding at the same time, like stepping on the gas and brake simultaneously.
explanation.key_insight: DIC is NEVER a primary diagnosis - always ask 'What's causing this?' Sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications are the most common triggers. Treating DIC without addressing the underlying cause is futile.
explanation.technical_details: Tissue factor exposure activates the extrinsic pathway. Thrombin generation causes fibrin deposition in microvasculature. Consumption of factors I (fibrinogen), V, VIII, and platelets causes bleeding. Secondary fibrinolysis from plasmin generates D-dimers. The ISTH scoring system uses platelet count, D-dimer, fibrinogen, and PT prolongation.

definitions_glossary.disseminated_intravascular_coagulation: Consumptive coagulopathy with systemic thrombin generation, microvascular thrombosis, and factor/platelet consumption
definitions_glossary.tissue_factor: Cell-surface glycoprotein initiating extrinsic coagulation; released in trauma, sepsis, malignancy
definitions_glossary.consumptive_coagulopathy: Depletion of clotting factors and platelets from excessive coagulation activation
definitions_glossary.fibrinogen: Coagulation factor I; converted to fibrin by thrombin; low in DIC from consumption
definitions_glossary.D_dimer: Fibrin degradation product; elevated from breakdown of cross-linked fibrin clots
definitions_glossary.schistocyte: Fragmented RBC from shearing on fibrin strands in microvasculature
definitions_glossary.ISTH_DIC_score: International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis scoring system for overt DIC
definitions_glossary.Trousseau_syndrome: Chronic DIC with venous thromboembolism in malignancy (especially mucin-secreting cancers)
definitions_glossary.acute_promyelocytic_leukemia: AML subtype classically causing DIC from granule-released procoagulants
definitions_glossary.obstetric_DIC: DIC triggered by placental abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, or septic abortion
definitions_glossary.sepsis_DIC: Most common cause of DIC; bacterial products trigger tissue factor expression
definitions_glossary.fibrinolysis: Breakdown of fibrin clots by plasmin; secondary activation in DIC

pathophysiology.mechanism: Systemic tissue factor exposure → thrombin generation → microvascular fibrin deposition + consumption of clotting factors and platelets → bleeding + organ dysfunction

phases.initiation: Tissue factor release from damaged cells or inflammatory cells
phases.propagation: Thrombin generation activates platelets and factors V, VIII, XI
phases.consumption: Factors I, V, VIII, platelets consumed faster than produced
phases.fibrinolysis: Plasmin activation degrades fibrin → elevated D-dimer

pathophysiology.organ_dysfunction: Microvascular thrombosis causes ischemia in kidneys, lungs, brain, liver

common_triggers.sepsis: Most common cause; bacterial products activate tissue factor on monocytes/endothelium
common_triggers.trauma_major: Tissue injury releases tissue factor; massive transfusion may worsen

malignancy.solid_tumors: Mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas (pancreas, GI, prostate) → chronic DIC/Trousseau
malignancy.hematologic: APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) has high DIC risk from granule release

criteria: Fibrin markers (D-dimer): no increase (0), moderate (2), strong (3)
ISTH_DIC_score.interpretation: Score ≥5 = overt DIC; <5 = possible non-overt DIC - repeat in 24h

clinical_phenotypes.acute_overt_DIC: Fulminant bleeding predominates; low platelets, very low fibrinogen

differential_diagnosis: Severe liver disease (also has prolonged PT, low fibrinogen, but high factor VIII)
Primary fibrinolysis (very low fibrinogen, normal/low D-dimer)

treat_underlying_cause.APL: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) - rapidly improves coagulopathy

supportive_transfusion.platelets: Transfuse if <50 and active bleeding or planned procedure; <10-20 prophylactically
supportive_transfusion.FFP: Transfuse if PT >1.5× normal and bleeding; target to near-normal PT
supportive_transfusion.cryoprecipitate: Transfuse if fibrinogen <100 mg/dL; each unit raises ~5-10 mg/dL
supportive_transfusion.fibrinogen_concentrate: Alternative to cryo; more concentrated and pathogen-reduced

anticoagulation.indications: Predominantly thrombotic phenotype (chronic DIC, Trousseau, purpura fulminans)
anticoagulation.agents: Heparin (controversial in acute DIC with bleeding); anticoagulate Trousseau syndrome
anticoagulation.caution: Avoid in overt bleeding DIC; may worsen hemorrhage

do_NOT_do: Do not treat DIC without addressing underlying cause
Do not give antifibrinolytics (TXA) in DIC - may worsen thrombosis

definition.@value: A syndrome of systemic intravascular coagulation activation leading to microvascular thrombosis and consumption of clotting factors and platelets, always secondary to an underlying disorder

scopeNote.@value: Critical coagulation emergency requiring treatment of underlying cause

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical and laboratory features of DIC
Apply the ISTH DIC scoring system
Implement appropriate transfusion support based on clinical phenotype
Prioritize treatment of underlying cause over supportive measures
clinical_pearls: DIC is NEVER primary - always identify and treat the underlying cause
Sepsis is the most common cause; APL is the classic hematologic cause
Low fibrinogen (<100) is highly specific for DIC vs other causes of prolonged PT
Chronic/compensated DIC (Trousseau) presents with thrombosis, not bleeding
In APL, start ATRA immediately - dramatically improves DIC even before chemo
common_misconceptions: DIC always causes bleeding - chronic DIC may present with thrombosis (Trousseau)
Anticoagulation is always contraindicated - may be indicated in thrombotic phenotype
Transfusions treat DIC - they're supportive only; treating the cause is essential
